newsitem.title: UK: Kwik Save aims to stem sales fall by yr-end.
newsitem.headline: Kwik Save aims to stem sales fall by yr-end.

text.p: British discount supermarket chain Kwik Save Group Plc would like to see its like-for-like sales recover to be unchanged or positive by the end of this calendar year, chief executive Graeme Bowler told journalists at a news conference.
"We would like to arrest the like-for-like decline, to neutral or positive by the end of the calendar year," he said.

Kwik Save said earlier on Thursday that same store sales in the first seven weeks of the second half were down six percent, after a fierce price war this time last year brought in new customers from the catering trade.
Bowler said the company estimated that exceptional trading last year accounted for around two percent of the comparable decline.

He added that although currently the group did not expect a repeat of the price war, which saw retailers selling tins of baked beans as cheaply as three pence per can, "we are in an industry which tears itself apart periodically and we can't stay on the sidelines."

Kwik Save reported on Thursday that half-year, pre- tax profits before exceptionals inched up to 44.8 million stg from 44.2 million stg previously and paid out an unchanged dividend of 5.95 pence per share.
The group is undergoing a three-year restructuring programme aimed at boosting sales and profits.
Bowler said although the company had been expecting a fall in sales during the current period,"We weren't expecting them to be down six percent".
He said the recovery strategy was "a long programme", but added that it would be a demonstration of the company rewarding shareholders for their patience if possible.
